name: Liver
question1: Describe the anatomy of the liver?  What are hepatic zones?
contents:
• Adult liver weights approximately 1.8g-2g


  • Divided into the right and left hemi-liver + caudate lobe
  • Histological unit of the liver is the LOBULE.
  • Lobules are hexagonal in shape
  • Several portal triads (hepatic artery, portal vein, bile duct) located at the corners (periphery)
  • Central vein (branch of hepatic vein) is present in the centre - surrounded by hepatocytes
  • Sinusoids traverse the lobule - draining nlood from the pheral portal triads to the central vein
  • Sinusoids also contain Kupffer cells, part of the reticuloendothelial system
  • Hepatocytes produce bile, which is excreted onot the hepatic ducts of the portal triad via the bile canaliculi
  • Functional unit of the liver is the ACINUS
  • A diamond shaped area of the liver supplied by a terminal branch of the portal vein and of the hepatic artery and drained by a terminal brain of the bile duct.
  • The liver acinus is divided into zones 1-3.
  • Zone 1
  • The portal triad is composed of the hepatic artery, portal vein and bile duct.
  • It is the portal triad that forms the centre of the acinus and as such forms zone 1.
  • rich in Oxygen - Mitochondria-rich cells - suited to:
  • Oxidative metabolism and
  • Glycogen synthesis.
  • Zone 3
  • receives blood that has already undergone exchange of gases and metabolites with cells in zones 1 and 2.
  • Zone 3 is rich in smooth endoplasmic reticulum and cytochrome p450, making this a key region for drug and toxin biotransformation.
  • Zone most at risk of cellular damage during circulatory disturbance.


HORGASM (hydrolysis, oxidation, reduction) (glucuronidation, acetylation, sulphation, methylation)

  • ○ Phase 1 = hydrolysis (also occurs e.g. in plasma), oxidation (CYP450 esp), reduction
  • ■ Unmasks polar bodies
  • ■ Phenothiazines, paracetamol, steroids
  • ■ Sufficient for excretion of some drugs; others require phase 2
  • ○ Phase 2 = glucuronidation, acetylation, sulphation, methylation
  • ■ Adding groups to drugs = referred to as conjugation reactions
  • ■ May have phase 2 without phase 1
question2: Discuss the functions of the liver.  (7 categories).
contents2:
Describe the biotransformation, synthetic (4), metabolic (5), digestive (ie, bile) storage (6), and other categories(2) excretory functions of the liver


  • (1) Biotransformation.
  • Phase 1 and Phase 2 reactions
  • Factors determining hepatic clearance.
  • proportion of unbound drug in the plasma
  • rate of drug presentation to the liver (flow limited) - important for drugs with high first-pass metabolism. eg morphine and lignocaine.
  • rate of enzymatic breakdown (ie, capacity limited) - important for drugs with low first-pass metabolism. - eg diazepam and warfarin.
  • increased or decreased by hepatic enzyme inducers/inductors.
  • (2) Synthetic function
  • Bile production
  • Plasma proteins including:
  • Clotting factors (except VIII)
  • Albumin production
  • 120-300mg.kg (7.2g) of albumin is produced per day, dependent on nutritional status, plasma oncotic pressure, and endocrine function.
  • (3) Metabolic functions
  • Carbohydrate - glycogenesis, gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis.
  • Fat - synthesises cholesterol and triglycerides.
  • Protein - synthesises transaminates or deaminates proteins. converts ammonia to less toxic urea.
  • Ketone bodies - produces acetoacetaate and beta-hydroxybutyrate.
  • Vitamins - activates Vitamin D
  • Bilirubin metabolism
  • Drugs and Toxins
  • (4) Digestive
  • liver produces bile.
  • Bile is primarily used for the emulsification of dietary lipids to allow their absorption.
  • In addition, bile is required for the absorption of fat soluable vitamins A,D,E,and K
  • (5) Storage
  • (1) Carbohydrates as glycogen
  • The adult liver stores ~100g of glycogen.
  • (2) Fat as triglycerides
  • (3) All fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K)
  • (4) Many water soluble vitamins including folic acid and B
  • (5) Iron
  • (6) Copper
  • (6) Capacitance
  • at any one time the liver can hold as much as 15% of the circulating volume and therefore can act as a large blood reservoir.
  • approximately half of this can be returned to the circulation during periods of sympathetic stimulation.
  • (7) Immunological
  • Kupffer cells
  • Tissue macrophages of the hepatic reticuloendothelial system.
  • They phagocytose harmful substances including:
  • Endotoxins
  • Bacteria
  • Viruses
  • Immune complexes
  • Thrombin
  • Fibrin complexes
  • Tumour cells

Others:

Endocrine

  • Produces angiotensinogen
  • Produces IGF-1
  • Converts T4 to T3

Acid-Base balance

May produce or consume large numbers of hydrogen ions:

  • Carbon dioxide production
  • Metabolism of organic acid anions
  • Lactate
  • Ketones
  • Amino acids
  • Ammonium
  • Production of plasma proteins
  • Notably albumin
question3: Describe the blood supply to the liver? What factors affect blood supply to the liver?
contents3:
• The liver is an extremely vascular organ, receiving a blood supply of 100ml/kg/min (approx 1800L/min)
  • It has a dual blood supply, receiving:
  • 70% of its blood flow from the portal vein
  • The portal vein is formed by the union of:
  • splenic vein and
  • superior mesenteric vein and thus carries blood from the GI tract to the liver.
  • the hepatic portal vein only has an oxygen saturation of approximately 70% and so it only provides around 40% of the livers oxygen requirements
  • 30% from the hepatic artery
  • is a branch of the coeliac artery
  • the hepatic artery provides approximately 60% of the livers oxygen requirements
  • Normal hepatic oxygen extraction is < 50% however this can increase in times of demand.



Blood flow through the hepatic artery is autoregulated (maintenance of constant flow despite fluctuations in BP)

In contrast blood flow through the portal vein is passive and dependent on splanchnic blood flow

Therefore only the arterial component of hepatic blood flow is controllable - the hepatic arterial blood flow is under intrinsic and extrinsic control

Intrinsic :

  • Myogenic
  • Hepatic arterial buffer response

Extrinsic

  • SNS -
  • Drugs
  • GA and spinal
question4: What is bioavailability? What is first pass metabolism? Why is it relevant?
contents4:
Bioavailability is the proportion of drug given which reaches the systemic circulation unchanged, compared to the IV form.

  • It is affected by:
  • Formulation
  • Physicochemical Interactions
  • Interactions with other drugs and food.
  • Patient Factors
  • Malabsorption syndrome
  • Gastric stasis
  • First-pass metabolism


First-pass (pre-systemic) metabolism is the extent to which drug concentration is reduced after its first passage through an organ, prior to reaching the systemic circulation.

First pass metabolism is:

  • Typically used when referring to passage of orally administered drugs through the liver
  • May also refer to metabolism by the:
  • Lungs
  • First pass of intravenously injected drugs prior to entering the arterial side of the circulation, e.g. fentanyl.
  • Vascular endothelium
  • Relevant in:
  • Understanding differences between PO and IV dosing
  • Alternative routes of administration for drugs with low PO bioavailability
  • Delivery of prodrugs via PO mechanisms
  • Increases active drug concentration.
  • Understanding enzyme interactions
  • Understanding the effects of hepatic disease
  • Porto-systemic shunts decrease first pass metabolism
  • Altered bioavailability of drugs with high hepatic extraction ratios


I presume that HER is not necessarily relevant in IV administered drugs??

Basically the GI tract and the liver are in the way - on the way to the systemic circulation - so any issues/changes will have an impact...
question5: -Describe the physiology of bile and its metabolism
contents5:
Bile is a dark green solution produced by the liver to facilitate absorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins (ADEK) through emulsification.

Bile is:

  • Produced by the liver at the rate of 1L per day
  • Concentrated in the gallbladder
  • Important in the absorbance of lipid and fat-soluble vitamins
  • Formed from:
  • Water
  • Protein
  • Bilirbuin
  • Bile salts
  • The sodium and potassium salts of bile acids. Bile acids:
  • Are are produced from cholesterol
  • Are amphipathic, and act as emulsifiers of lipid
  • Break up large fat globules into smaller micelles, which can then be absorbed.
  • Major bile acids include:
  • Cholic acid
  • Chenodeoxycholic acid
  • Are absorbed in the terminal ileum, and recycled by the portal circulation
  • Lipids
  • Electrolytes
